transcript:
Patient: One situation where setting a boundary might be helpful is when my family members drop by unannounced and expect me to entertain them, even if I'm in the middle of something important or need time to myself.

Therapist: That's a great example. Setting boundaries around your time and space can help you protect your well-being and avoid feelings of resentment or overwhelm. When setting a boundary, it's important to be clear, specific, and consistent. You might say something like, "I value our time together, but I also need some notice before you come over to make sure I'm available. In the future, could you please call or text me before dropping by?"

How do you think setting this boundary could impact your relationships with your family members?

Patient: I think setting this boundary could help me feel more respected and in control of my own time and space. It might be challenging at first, as my family members are used to dropping by whenever they want, but I think it could lead to more positive interactions in the long run.

Therapist: You're right, setting boundaries can be challenging, especially when it involves changing long-standing patterns in relationships. Remember that it's normal for people to react with surprise or even resistance at first. The key is to remain calm, firm, and consistent in upholding your boundaries. Over time, most people will adapt to and respect the new boundaries you've set.

As we wrap up today's session, I want to check in with you. How are you feeling about the progress we've made and the strategies we've discussed?

Patient: I'm feeling more empowered and hopeful. I can see how practicing assertiveness and setting boundaries could help improve my relationships and overall well-being. I know it won't be easy, but I'm committed to working on these skills.

Therapist: It's great to hear that you're feeling empowered and hopeful. Remember that progress takes time, and it's normal to experience setbacks along the way. The important thing is to keep practicing and be patient with yourself.

For homework, I'd like you to continue monitoring your thoughts and practicing the assertiveness techniques we discussed. Try to identify at least one situation where you can practice setting a boundary and using "I" statements. In our next session, we can review your experiences and continue building on these skills.

Patient: That sounds good. I'll do my best to practice these techniques and come prepared to discuss my experiences in our next session.

Therapist: Great. If you have any questions or concerns between now and our next session, please don't hesitate to reach out. Remember, you're making important strides in your journey towards better mental health, and I'm here to support you every step of the way.
